events.text:
A new series where I look at
esoteric programming languages
(or esolangs for short)

If you are not already
aware...

A programming language for the
often forgotten whitespace characters!

* created by Edwin Brady, Chris Morris,
  and Andrew Stribblehill

-> All of these characters
   display as nothing in
   most fonts.

This makes Whitespace kind of
hard to display.

Yeah, we're gonna need another
way to look at this.
For this video, I'm going with:

So the excerpt from the previous
screenshot would actually look 
like this:

which... is still not easy to
decipher but at least we can see
it now!

Let's talk about 
how to actually read 
this... thing

(keep in mind these
just represent
characters that
actually appear
invisible)

Whitespace is a stack-based,
imperative language.

If you're in a rush and already
know what those words mean, you
can skip to:

The stack is a Data Structure
based on Last-In-First-Out.

* It acts like a physical stack
  of objects.

* You can add objects to the top,
  called pushing.

* And you can only take objects
  from the top, called popping.

I couldn't pop 1, since it's not
at the top of the stack.

I have to pop 2 first, /then/ pop
1.

I can only directly operate on the
top of the stack.

* Effectively a compact way of writing
  stack operations

* To most people, this looks like
  nonsense.

Whenever we come across a
number in a postfix expr., we
push it to the top of the 
stack.

This tells us to pop the top
two numbers, add them, and
push the result to the stack.

Subtraction, unlike the
others, is NOT commutative.

So, we need to decide on the
order.

And that's the result from
evaluating this postfix
expression!

In infix expressions, you'd
write this as:

This is, in essence, how
stack-based languages work.

-> Take it off the stack to
   put it somewhere else

However, there is a bit more
that you can do with the
stack.

-> Instructions are done in
   the order they're
   written in.

Most stack-based languages
operate this way, and
Whitespace is no exception.

Welcome back to those who skipped the 
previous section!

Every whitespace instruction begins with a
prefix telling you what kind of instruction
it is.

* The official documentation calls this
  an "Instruction Modification Parameter"
  which is way too fancy for what it
  actually is.

These are just categories that exist for
organizational purposes.

Each IMP has its own instructions that go
after the IMP.

After the instruction, there's an optional
parameter, which some instructions have and
some don't.

* Parameters can either be a number or a
  label.
Numbers are a little more complex.

Boom! We just wrote a
number in Whitespace.

Now that we know how to write
parameters, let's actually look at some
instructions.

S
S
S
S
S
S

S
NS
NT
NN
TS
TN

Push [Number]
Duplicate
Swap
Drop
Copy [Number]
Slide [Number]
Duplicate top item on the stack

Copies the nth item on the stack
to the top

Copies the 2nd item on the 
stack to the top

Swap the top two items on the
stack
Drops the top item on the stack

Drops n items /below/ the top item
on the stack (sliding)

Addition
Subtraction
Multiplication
Integer Division
Modulo

* All of these pop two numbers and do
  an operation, where the first number
  popped is on the right of the
  operator, and the second is on the
  left.

* Note that the only type of division
  available is *integer* division.
  This is because Whitespace only
  allows integral numbers.

* Whitespace's heap is just an
  infinitely long tape of numbers,
  indexed by another number, called
  an [address].

-> Takes a value from the stack,
   then an address, and stores
   that value to that address.

-> Pops an address from the stack
   and pushes the value at that
   address on the heap to the
   stack.

N
N
N
N
N
N
N

Label [Label]
Call Subroutine [Label]
Unconditional Jump [Label]
Jump If {top} < 0 [Label]
Jump If {top} != 0 [Label]
Return
End

SS
ST
SN
TS
TT
TN
NN

These instructions move around the
program in various ways.
Marks a place in the program.

Marks the current place with
the label TN.

Jumps to the place previously
marked TN.

Pops a value, if it's zero then
it jumps to the label, otherwise
does nothing.

Similar, except it only jumps if
the value is less than zero.

Stops executing and ends the
program; this is required at the
end of any program that
terminates.

Calls a label. Similar to jump,
except when a return is run,
the program returns back to where
this instruction is.

Output Character
Output Number
Input Character
Input Number

Output Instructions pop
something from the top
of the stack.

Outputs top of the
stack as a Unicode
codepoint.

Outputs the top of
the stack as a
number.

Input Instructions take
some input from the
user before continuing.
This input is stored on
the heap.

Reads a character
from the user and
stores it as a
Unicode codepoint.

Reads a number
from the user and
stores it.

And that's it! For instructions at
least...

Let's actually write something in this
language, finally!

-> Generally, the first thing someone
   does in a new programming language is
   write a "Hello, World!" program.

-> In whitespace, we need a combination
   of Push and Output Character
   instructions to achieve this.

TNSS

This is to save
time; some
letters are
repeats, so we
can duplicate
some ahead of
time and print
them out later.

Yeah, that's not as easy as
just writing

Of course, that's not the 
/only/ program you can write 
with this language.

* This means you can write
  pretty much any program you
  want in it.

Another simple program is
cat (named after the UNIX cat
utility)

* The cat program simply copies
  its input to its output.

NSSTN
SSSSN
SNS
TNTS
TTT
TNSS
NSNTN

Note that since this program
never terminates, we do not
end up needing an End
instruction.

SSSSN
SNS
TNTT
TTT
NTSTN

NSSSN
SSSTN
TNST
NSNSN

NSSTN
SSSSN
TNST
NNN

The truth machine takes an
input, either 0 or 1. If
it's 0, then it outputs
0 and exits. If it's 1,
then it repeats forever,
outputting 1 every
iteration.
So, why would you ever use

Well, it doesn't have much practical
use, other than being a thing for
programmers like myself to waste
their time on when they're bored.

But maybe, just maybe, it has another
use:

As far as I can tell, Whitespace is
not used nor discussed much even
inside esolang circles.

So overall, it wasn't that influential
of an Esolang.

However, some impressive things have
been done in it.

* For example, Oliver Burghard wrote
  a Whitespace interpreter /in/
  Whitespace.

Notice how none of these are such
pointless things as "usability",
or "ergonomics" or "expresiveness".
Esolangs are more of an artform.

* Whitespace gets points for how
  it only uses whitespace
  characters.

* The way the language works isn't
  very original; it's very similar
  to other stack-based languages.

* Whitespace doesn't offer much of
  a challenge to program in.

* Most problems can be worked
  around by implementing a basic
  assembler.

* There is enjoyment value in
  Whitespace is the absurdity that
  an empty text file is fully
  functional code

* Anyone could probably come up with
  Whitespace.

* Whitespace's specific design isn't
  really that impressive either.

* It /is/ a language using only
  whitespace characters

* Quite a few whitespace
  characters are missing.

* Missing: NO-BREAK SPACE
  OGHAM SPACE MARK,
  MONGOLIAN VOWEL
  SEPARATOR, EN QUAD, EM 
  QUAD, EN SPACE, EM 
  SPACE, FIGURE SPACE,
  PUNCTUATION SPACE, THIN
  SPACE, HAIR SPACE, ZERO
  WIDTH SPACE, and more!

Because of that, I can't
give Whitespace a full 4/4.
